conversation.text: I'm in the mood for a murder movie. Could you recommend a few?

conversation.speaker: SYSTEM
conversation.text: Based on your preference cues for a murder movie, I would recommend "The Lovely Bones" and "Capote". "The Lovely Bones" is a mystery-thriller film directed by Peter Jackson and based on the novel of the same name by Alice Sebold. The film tells the story of a young girl who has been murdered and watches over her family  - and her killer  - from purgatory. She must weigh her desire for vengeance against her desire for her family to heal. "Capote" is a biographical drama film directed by David Fincher and based on the novel of the same name by Truman Capote. The film tells the story of how Capote, who was then known as Robert Culp, discovered and wrote the book about the murder of a Kansas family.

Peter must act fast to stop the terrorists before they are able to carry out their devious plan. Will Peter win out in the end? Or will the terrorists get the upper hand? Find out in this highly intense original movie that is the standard of all spy movies. And unite for a hero that will live on as the ultimate spy reconnoiter since the advent of James Bond.

conversation.text:
Based on the user's preferences, I would recommend the movie "War Horse".

This historical drama is based on Michael Morpurgo's novel and adapted for the stage by Nick Stafford.

The film tells the story of a young boy named Joey who lives with his foster parents in rural Devon, England.

Joey loves horses and spends most of his time outdoors with his friends and animals.

When World War I breaks out, Joey is sent to France to serve as a soldier in the British Army.

While serving as a soldier, Joey becomes very close friends with two other soldiers named Tomboy and Little Women.

As the war continues on, Joey, Tomboy, Little Women, and many other soldiers from all over the world are forced to continue fighting against the enemy even though they have grown tired of continuing fighting and killing each other day after day after day.
.
